abstract.para: An overview of how to use the couchdb-maven-plugin

section.title: Developing Couch Applications
section.para:
The plugin defines a new packaging type and so you must ensure that extensions is set to true in your plugin declaration:
Adding the plugin to a project <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"> ...
<build> <!-- To define the plugin version in your parent POM --> <pluginManagement> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId></groupId> <artifactId></artifactId> <version></version> <extensions>true</extensions> </plugin>
... </plugins> </pluginManagement> <!-- To use the plugin goals in your POM or parent POM --> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId></groupId> <artifactId></artifactId> <version></version> <extensions>true</extensions> </plugin>
... </plugins> </build>
... </project>

With this done, you can then declare projects with a packaging of couchapp:
Defining a couchapp project <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"> <groupId>my.group.id</groupId> <artifactId>some-couch-project</artifactId> <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version> <packaging>couchapp</packaging> ... </project>
which will bind the default set of couchapp goals to the lifecycle.

Couchapps should be placed under couchapp.sourceDirectory, which defaults to: ${basedir}src/main/couchapp.
The directory structure is as follows:
src/main/couchapp/ |- application_1/ | |- views/ | |- view_1/ | | |- map.js | | |- reduce.js (optional) | |- view_2/ | |- map.js |- application_2/ (optional) ... same as above ...

section.title: Working with Couch DB Instances
section.para:
The plugin also provides a set of goals for working directly with live CouchDB instances, including document retrieval and deployment of couchapps.
These goals all require additional configuration; specifically the host, port, authentication details and database name of the couch server. Currently only basic security is supported.
